summary_reasoning: The report provides high originality by moving beyond headline earnings to offer quantified, company-specific mechanisms for growth and competitive advantage. It features at least four distinct syntheses that are highly decision-relevant. Most notably, the analyst provides an original thesis on pricing power by extracting data from regulatory pricing disclosures (quantifying the 2025 list price at 8.10 bps and the minimum fee at $145,000), which serves as a specific, testable evidence base for the firm's 'wide moat.' Additionally, the report synthesizes the value proposition of the ratings business by contrasting the cost of a rating (~8 bps) against the interest savings for issuers (30-65 bps), providing a clear economic mechanism for the firm's pricing floor. The analysis of the mobility spinoff and the margin trajectory (forecasting 52% by 2029 despite the IHS Markit integration) provides specific, quantified pathways for valuation. Finally, the report offers actionable peer-specific insights, such as using S&P’s Market Intelligence performance as a negative read-through for FactSet. These elements—quantified implications, explicit causal links, and peer contrasts—meet the criteria for an Excellent grade.

insights_classified.text: S&P raised its January 2025 list price by about 2.5% year over year on corporate bond ratings to 8.10 basis points from 7.90 basis points... increased the minimum fee on most corporate transactions to $145,000.

By getting a bond rating from a market leader such as S&P, the bond issuer pays less in interest (often 30-65 basis points in savings per year) [vs] cost of a vanilla corporate bond credit rating costs around 8 basis points.
We expect S&P Global to reach about 52% adjusted operating margins in 2029, which compares with 49% in 2024... given the inclusion of IHS Markit, which has some lower-margin businesses.

S&P Global notes that it is seeing a highly competitive environment in financial services and somewhat elevated price sensitivity in Market Intelligence. Overall, we view this as a negative sign for narrow-moat-rated FactSet.
S&P’s mobility division... had limited relevance to S&P’s other segments, so the spinoff makes sense.
